item.title: One of my favorite puzzle games with 96% positive reviews just fell to its lowest price ever on Steam
item.itunes:title: One of my favorite puzzle games with 96% positive reviews just fell to its lowest price ever on Steam
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
It's a good day if you're into puzzle games. A little while ago, I reported that Chants of Sannaar, which holds a spot in my pantheon of "favorite puzzle games ever," was discounted as part of a Steam sale. Now, another one from that pantheon, Return of the Obra Dinn, has just gone on sale. It's as if someone at Valve has both a love for puzzle games and impeccable taste.

Return of the Obra Dinn is 50% off on Steam right now

Return of the Obra Dinn follows your average detective-style gameplay. People have died, and you need to figure out how they were taken out and who did the deed, if anyone. However, there's a catch: all the deaths happened five years ago, and all that remains are the skeletons of the crew and some scraps.

Fortunately, you have a watch that allows you to see the exact moment when someone died, as if it were a freeze frame. From here, you can see who attacked whom, who was skulking in the shadows, and even further clues into the fate of the crew.

Once you figure it out, you log the cause of death and the attacker, if any, in your book. Once you've gotten a trio of the crew correct, the game will lock them in. Your objective is to get your entire book filled out so you can file your findings to an insurance company.

Here's the Steam page listing:

In 1802, the merchant ship Obra Dinn set out from London for the Orient with over 200 tons of trade goods. Six months later it hadn't met its rendezvous point at the Cape of Good Hope and was declared lost at sea.

Early this morning of October 14th, 1807, the Obra Dinn drifted into port at Falmouth with damaged sails and no visible crew. As insurance investigator for the East India Company's London Office, dispatch immediately to Falmouth, find means to board the ship, and prepare an assessment of damages.

Return of the Obra Dinn is a first-person mystery adventure based on exploration and logical deduction.

Right now, Return of the Obra Dinn is 50% off on Steam until October 23rd, selling for a very reasonable $10. It's the lowest the game has ever been on Steam, beating its previous 40% discount record. And if you need more convincing, we named it one of the best indie games that everyone should play once in their lives.

item.title: Microsoft fixes one of the more annoying dual-screen issues with Windows 11
item.itunes:title: Microsoft fixes one of the more annoying dual-screen issues with Windows 11
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
Summary

  • Canary build lets you open Notification Center on any monitor, showing calendar and clock with seconds.
  • Fixes File Explorer network transfer crash, lock screen media, pen/handwriting issues, and protected content playback.
  • Known issues: Settings may crash on drive info, Start may scroll to top, sleep/shutdown problems reported.

While we've only just waved goodbye to Windows 10's feature updates, Windows 11 continues as normal. After all, with Windows 11 now being the only operating system Microsoft supports with anything more than security updates, it needs to keep things fresh and exciting for its users.

In fact, I'd argue that it has to make things as comfortable for former Windows 10 users as possible, as keeping them bereft of the features they've come to know and love may encourage them to switch to another operating system instead of sticking with Windows 11. Fortunately, it seems Microsoft is in the same boat as me, as it's finally fixing one of the more annoying issues of using Windows 11 on a dual-screen setup.

Microsoft finally allows Windows 11 users to open the Notification Center on either monitor

Over on the Windows Insider blog, Microsoft shares the patch notes for its newest Windows 11 update. It's currently on the Canary channel, which is the very first round of public testing before the patch arrives on the Beta, Dev, and Release preview channels. As such, we won't see this update on the release branch for a little while, but it's making its way over at the very least.

There isn't a ton of additions for Preview Build 27971, but the highlight feature is the addition of the Notification Center on secondary monitors. This means you can see the time and date on either of your monitors, and Microsoft notes that this includes the new feature that adds a clock with seconds above the calendar. Also, it appears the patch fixes that weird box that's causing protected content from playing.

One tweak actually addresses an issue that Canary users experienced with earlier patches. If you're on the Canary branch and File Explorer keeps crashing when you move things onto a network drive, this update should fix that.

Here are the full notes:

[Notification Center]

  • We are extending the functionality of Notification Center to secondary monitors. This means you will be able to see your calendar on any of your monitors as well as the option to show a bigger clock with seconds above calendar. You will be able to open Notification Center on any monitor by clicking the date and time in the system tray of your taskbar.

[We are beginning to roll this out to Windows Insiders in the Canary, so the experience isn’t available to all Insiders just yet as we plan to monitor feedback before pushing it out to everyone.]

Fixes

[File Explorer]

  • Fixed an issue in the latest Canary builds causing File Explorer to crash when transferring files to a network drive.

[Lock and login screens]

  • Fixed an issue in the previous build where the media controls might not display on the lock screen.

[Input]

  • Fixed an underlying issue related to microsoft.ink.dll and relevant APIs, which could result in pen and handwriting not working correctly in apps or app crashes recently due to unexpected exceptions being thrown.

[Other]

  • Fixed an underlying issue which was causing protected content playback to fail for some apps recently.
  • Fixed an issue impacting the ability to start Hyper-V virtual machines with Trusted Platform Module (TPM) on ARM64 devices.

Known issues

[Settings]

  • Settings may crash when accessing drive information under Settings > System > Storage. This also impacts accessing the drive information from the properties when you right click a drive in File Explorer.

[Start menu]

  • [NEW] Insiders with the new Start menu may experience it unexpectedly scrolling to the top.

[Power and Battery]

  • We’re investigating reports that sleep and shutdown aren’t working correctly for some Insiders after the latest Canary builds.

item.title: How I combined Rocketbook and Obsidian to automate my physical note-taking
item.itunes:title: How I combined Rocketbook and Obsidian to automate my physical note-taking
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
I'm old-school and take most of my notes by hand, but I hate re-typing them into a note-taking app later. Thankfully, I've stumbled across a solution that not only handles most of the tedium for me but also saves me a lot of money on paper: a combination of Rocketbook and Obsidian. I take my notes in Rocketbook, a reusable notebook with a FriXion pen that can easily be erased. When I scan the page, it's automatically uploaded to my iCloud drive and then to Obsidian. There are other ways of doing this — in fact, setting up the entire system in Google Drive would likely be easier — but since I already use iCloud as a backup solution, this slots into my day-to-day workflow much more easily.

The setup process is a bit of a pain. It's not too complicated, but there are more steps than there need to be for something like this. Don't worry, though; all you iOS users in the same boat as me will find an easy solution to a problem that really should have already been solved with an Obsidian plugin. Seriously: why isn't there better Rocketbook integration already?

The root of this entire problem lies in iCloud. It creates a dedicated subfolder named after any third-party app, which makes access tricky. As a result of this, rather than syncing Rocketbook uploads directly into my Obsidian folder, I have to use an automation to move uploads.

How to automatically transfer Rocketbook files into Obsidian

Due to iCloud's eccentricities with third-party applications, there are two main folders that come into play here. The first is the Rocketbook folder, created by the Rocketbook app itself. The second is my Obsidian folder, which contains multiple subfolders — one for each of my vaults. In this particular circumstance, I need the files from the Rocketbook folder to move into the correct Obsidian vault subfolder. Sounds complicated, right? It could be worse. I'd rate this setup as medium difficulty, so let's get started.

Set up the correct Rocketbook destination

  1. Open Rocketbook on your iOS device.
  2. Tap Destinations in the bottom-right corner.
  3. By default, the destination will be Email. Tap Change Destination -> iCloud -> Create New Folder.
  4. Name the folder.
  5. Tap Save in the upper-right corner.

Once you've set up your iCloud folder as the destination, you can quickly select it anytime you scan in a new note, and it will send the file straight there. Now, we can move on to creating the automation.

Set up the file automation

  1. Open Shortcuts on your iOS device.
  2. Tap the Automation button in the bottom-center of the screen.
  3. Tap New Automation.
  4. This opens a menu that allows you to select the trigger that runs in the automation. Scroll down and select App.
  5. Tap App -> Rocketbook -> Done.
  6. Disable the toggle for Is Open and tap Is Closed.
  7. Tap Run Immediately -> Next.
  8. Tap New Blank Automation.
  9. Search for Get Contents of Folder and tap the light-blue Folder text beneath it, then select the Rocketbook folder you named earlier.
  10. Search your actions again for Move File. It will automatically populate the initial field with Get Contents of Folder, but you will need to tap Shortcuts, the default selection, and instead choose the folder for your Obsidian vault. In my case, I have a dedicated folder for Rocketbook uploads, but you can choose to send the files to your primary vault instead.
  11. Tap Done.

And with that, voilà: any file you upload to Rocketbook will automatically appear in your Obsidian vault as soon as you close the application. The reason I have it set to activate upon closing is that it allows me to move multiple notes at once.

It's convenient, and it saves the trees

As I said earlier, I take a lot of notes — but I always felt bad jotting things down that would be tossed later. It felt like a waste of paper. With the Rocketbook, I can take as many notes as I want and simply clean the page off later with a damp cloth. As long as I scan the notes with the Rocketbook app — a process that takes seconds — then they're preserved in a digital format for posterity. And when it comes to notes I don't need to keep, like calculations or random scribbles? I can easily erase those, and deletion is as simple as tapping an icon if one does accidentally get uploaded.

item.title: An iGPU can be a fantastic addition to your gaming PC, even with a dedicated GPU
item.itunes:title: An iGPU can be a fantastic addition to your gaming PC, even with a dedicated GPU
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
Integrated graphics built on desktop CPUs got a bad rap, especially for Intel in the 2010s which saw the introduction of a graphics core on the Clarkdale consumer desktop CPUs, which was the first generation of Intel Core i5 and i3 processors. Despite the bad reputation, the history of integrated graphics goes back more than a decade prior to Clarkdale.

Because of that reputation, you would be forgiven for thinking that an iGPU isn't particularly useful when your PC has a discrete graphics card. Yet there are a few key reasons to keep that iGPU enabled even if it seems counterintuitive at first. After all, integrated graphics have arguably become more interesting than dedicated GPUs for the last couple of generations. So, while you might be tempted to disable your gaming PC's integrated graphics (and they might even be enabled by default with a discrete GPU slotted into your motherboard), you might want to keep it enabled, anyway.

Uses of iGPUs

What can an iGPU do for your desktop?

Integrated graphics can run many basic tasks for your PC, freeing up GPU resources. Integrated Graphics can display web pages, handle video playback, and control office applications. Essentially, the iGPU can run your PC whenever you don't require the extra resources provided by your discrete graphics card.

So, unless you're in a game, editing videos, or doing some 3D rendering, your PC can run certain tasks using the iGPU. And if you've got multiple monitors or multiple programs open, you can dedicate your discrete GPU resources to your game while the iGPU keeps your Discord or streaming window operational.

Most motherboards only allow you to output from one GPU at a time, but the actual processing (not the rasterization and output) can still be done on the iGPU in the background. You can look for a setting along the lines of "iGPU Multi-Monitor" in your motherboard which will allow you to actually output using both the motherboard and your GPU's output ports.

The uses for an iGPU are even more obvious when thinking about it in a home server context. Chances are, the iGPU of your processor is more than enough to handle video transcoding, so you can transcode video at high resolution through technology like Intel QuickSync, without needing to spin up and power your discrete GPU.

iGPUs are more power-efficient

Integrated graphics can save you on your power bill

Not only can an iGPU handle a number of general-use tasks and even some light gaming, it's a far more power-efficient option compared to a discrete GPU.

While power efficiency is less important on a desktop than on a laptop, you don't always want your 300-500-watt GPU kicking on just because you need to check your email or want to play a YouTube video for background noise. While a discrete gaming GPU isn't likely to run at full power while just browsing the web, it still draws more power than the iGPU.

This is highly dependent on your graphics card, but a discrete GPU can idle from anywhere as low as 10W of power to 30W, though an iGPU will typically idle lower than 10W. Over time, those power savings will build up, especially if you use your gaming PC for work, school, or general web surfing and social media binges.

Modern laptops will seamlessly switch between integrated and discrete graphics depending on the workload in order to save battery power, and on a desktop, swapping between the iGPU and discrete GPU can save you some cash on your next power bill. Especially if you use your gaming PC for multiple purposes.

Integrated graphics can be your backup GPU

Just in case that discrete card goes sideways

Another reason to keep your integrated graphics card is that it can serve as a backup GPU. Just in case something goes sideways with your discrete card, you can still use your PC and even get some gaming in on the integrated graphics card while you diagnose and solve the issue with your discrete card, or wait for a replacement to show up in the mail.

This is especially helpful if you don't have an old GPU lying around, or if you've repurposed it for a home server or eGPU. Since it means your PC doesn't just become an oversized paperweight if your GPU stops working. That way, you can still use your PC to troubleshoot your hardware issues and research solutions.

There's no reason not to keep your iGPU enabled

Even if you almost never use it

It's difficult to buy a CPU that doesn't have an integrated graphics tile built in at this point. Both AMD and Intel desktop and laptop CPUs feature integrated graphics alongside the main compute unit, though AMD has been dropping CPUs for the AM5 platform without integrated graphics, and Intel's 'F' line of CPUs lack integrated graphics, too. With that said, it's worth trying to actually use your iGPU, particularly when it's still useful to run additional chat or streaming monitors, can save you money on your power bill, and can function as a backup GPU in case your RTX 5090 decided to set itself on fire.

Whether you use your iGPU to power multiple monitors, as a backup for a discrete GPU failure, or to save power, there are multiple uses for integrated graphics. And these uses don't have to replace your discrete GPU, but work flawlessly alongside it. So there's really no reason not to use that integrated graphics chip, even if you might think you don't need it.

item.title: Should you buy Battlefield 6 now or save your money for Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 next month?
item.itunes:title: Should you buy Battlefield 6 now or save your money for Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 next month?
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
It's that time of the year again. Wallets are tighter, game wishlists are longer, and both Battlefield and Call of Duty have arrived at the worst possible time for anyone trying to budget responsibly. Between dinners, parties, and holiday gifts, buying two big AAA shooters back-to-back isn't something all players would be able to do. In fact, it's an important buying decision for the entire friend group, who are going to be spending their available time with the squad on one game instead of constantly hopping between two.

If you've been staring at both Battlefield 6 and the upcoming Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 on your wishlist, and wondering which one deserves your money, this breakdown's for you. Sure, both games are heavyweights and Battlefield has never looked so good, but they still cater to very different kinds of players.

In sheer content, Call of Duty offers more

Even if Black Ops 7's campaign turns out to be a dud, the multiplayer is just as slick

Let's start with the cold, hard value proposition. Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 offers more bang for your buck right out of the gate. It's packing three major experiences — a full campaign, a Zombies mode with multiple maps, including the largest-ever Zombies map, and its multiplayer mode. We don't know a lot about Black Ops 7's co-op campaign, but the other two are both robust enough to stand on their own. That's a lot of content for one purchase, and if you're the kind of player who loves switching things up, it's hard to ignore that versatility.

On the other hand, Battlefield 6 sticks to the franchise's bread and butter: a short single-player campaign and its sprawling multiplayer. Unfortunately, the campaign this time around is a letdown. It's flashy and loud, yes, but it's also a complete misfire narratively, and from a gameplay perspective as well. Thankfully, the multiplayer more than makes up for it, because that's where Battlefield always shines. There's also the Battlefield Portal, which lets you play community-created maps, some of which are rather incredible.

So, in essence, Black Ops 7 gives you more modes, but Battlefield 6 gives you one truly great experience, which is its massive-scale warfare. Even if the Black Ops 7 campaign is a dud, the COD game will have one entire mode over Battlefield to offer its players. Plus, the Endgame for the campaign will be replayable, and even if you somehow manage to like the Battlefield 6 campaign, you won't be going back to play it regularly, or even frequently.

Both games offer different multiplayer experiences

It's chaos versus curation in the MP lobbies

Battlefield 6's multiplayer is a strong return to form, harkening back to Battlefield 3 and 4-era multiplayer gameplay with no performance issues. It's all-out chaos, and that's why people love it. It's huge, unpredictable, and built for "Only in Battlefield" moments of emergent madness that you simply can't script. You'll have Abram tanks rolling through villages, jets dogfighting in the sky, snipers on distant rooftops, and a dozen things exploding all at once while you look for the nearest trench to throw yourself into. The scale of the multiplayer maps here is nothing like Call of Duty offers players, and that is the game's greatest strength. It gives you the feeling of being part of something much larger than yourself.

On the flip side, Black Ops 7 offers the kind of tight, curated experience that only COD can deliver. The maps may be smaller, but every inch is polished and intentional. There's a rhythm to every firefight, and you can practically feel the designers' fingerprints in the sightlines, choke points, and cover placements. Of course, movement remains the signature of COD. In Black Ops 7, it's smoother than ever. Wall jumps, slides, and quick turns all flow together seamlessly, creating a fast-paced dance of reflexes that feels as buttery as it looks.

Where you'll get true immersion and scale in Battlefield to the point that you won't even be able to explore a full map without playing two or three matches, Call of Duty is about precision and intensity, and the new multiplayer maps are absolutely worth the time you'll spend grinding in them. They're tighter, the teams are smaller, and the gunplay is a lot faster.

SBMM vs. persistent lobbies is the biggest differentiator

Has Activision removed SBMM out of fear of Battlefield 6?

This is a big one. Battlefield 6 does have SBMM (skill-based matchmaking), meaning your matches are constantly reshuffled to put you against players of roughly-equal skill. It's a fair system, yes, but it can make multiplayer feel oddly sterile.

Black Ops 7, however, is going old-school. Developer Treyarch have announced that the game, at launch, will have persistent lobbies and no SBMM, which is something that COD players have been requesting.

This means you'll stay in the same match lobby between games, creating natural rivalries and that old-school sense of community over hours of playtime that we've missed since the Xbox 360 days. It's the kind of change that hardcore fans have been begging for, and it could make BO7's multiplayer far more social than Battlefield's.

Do you like your war simulator light-hearted?

Battlefield 6 has assured players it won't be chasing trends

Both studios have made it clear that they are doubling down on what defines their respective series. Battlefield 6 refuses to chase trends. There aren't going to be celebrity skins, pop-culture crossovers, or memes here. What you'll get is just grounded, gritty warfare. In fact, the studio even poked fun at Call of Duty's celebrity crossovers with one of their pre-launch trailers, which was a confident statement: "We know what we are."

Meanwhile, Call of Duty is playing a balancing act. The bevy of celebrity skins and even cartoons in the Black Ops 6 multiplayer from last year left a bad taste in the mouths of a major part of the player base, and after listening to their complaints, they stated in a community post that Black Ops 7 won't be carrying Black Ops 6's skins into its multiplayer. Its battle royale mode, Warzone, which is a standalone gameplay experience now, will continue to be the playground for all the pop-culture madness, but Black Ops 7 will still leave room for some wacky crossovers that the higher-ups convince themselves fit into the theme.

If you want a no-nonsense, boots-on-the-ground combat game that refuses to bow to trends, Battlefield 6 should be your pick. If you want the best of both worlds, where you get fast and fluid gameplay along with modern flair and a wall jumping mechanic, BO7 might have you covered instead.

item.content:encoded:
It's that time of the year again. Wallets are tighter, game wishlists are longer, and both Battlefield and Call of Duty have arrived at the worst possible time for anyone trying to budget responsibly. Between dinners, parties, and holiday gifts, buying two big AAA shooters back-to-back isn't something all players would be able to do. In fact, it's an important buying decision for the entire friend group, who are going to be spending their available time with the squad on one game instead of constantly hopping between two.

If you've been staring at both Battlefield 6 and the upcoming Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 on your wishlist, and wondering which one deserves your money, this breakdown's for you. Sure, both games are heavyweights and Battlefield has never looked so good, but they still cater to very different kinds of players.

In sheer content, Call of Duty offers more

Even if Black Ops 7's campaign turns out to be a dud, the multiplayer is just as slick

Let's start with the cold, hard value proposition. Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 offers more bang for your buck right out of the gate. It's packing three major experiences — a full campaign, a Zombies mode with multiple maps, including the largest-ever Zombies map, and its multiplayer mode. We don't know a lot about Black Ops 7's co-op campaign, but the other two are both robust enough to stand on their own. That's a lot of content for one purchase, and if you're the kind of player who loves switching things up, it's hard to ignore that versatility.

On the other hand, Battlefield 6 sticks to the franchise's bread and butter: a short single-player campaign and its sprawling multiplayer. Unfortunately, the campaign this time around is a letdown. It's flashy and loud, yes, but it's also a complete misfire narratively, and from a gameplay perspective as well. Thankfully, the multiplayer more than makes up for it, because that's where Battlefield always shines. There's also the Battlefield Portal, which lets you play community-created maps, some of which are rather incredible.

So, in essence, Black Ops 7 gives you more modes, but Battlefield 6 gives you one truly great experience, which is its massive-scale warfare. Even if the Black Ops 7 campaign is a dud, the COD game will have one entire mode over Battlefield to offer its players. Plus, the Endgame for the campaign will be replayable, and even if you somehow manage to like the Battlefield 6 campaign, you won't be going back to play it regularly, or even frequently.

Both games offer different multiplayer experiences

It's chaos versus curation in the MP lobbies

Battlefield 6's multiplayer is a strong return to form, harkening back to Battlefield 3 and 4-era multiplayer gameplay with no performance issues. It's all-out chaos, and that's why people love it. It's huge, unpredictable, and built for "Only in Battlefield" moments of emergent madness that you simply can't script. You'll have Abram tanks rolling through villages, jets dogfighting in the sky, snipers on distant rooftops, and a dozen things exploding all at once while you look for the nearest trench to throw yourself into. The scale of the multiplayer maps here is nothing like Call of Duty offers players, and that is the game's greatest strength. It gives you the feeling of being part of something much larger than yourself.

On the flip side, Black Ops 7 offers the kind of tight, curated experience that only COD can deliver. The maps may be smaller, but every inch is polished and intentional. There's a rhythm to every firefight, and you can practically feel the designers' fingerprints in the sightlines, choke points, and cover placements. Of course, movement remains the signature of COD. In Black Ops 7, it's smoother than ever. Wall jumps, slides, and quick turns all flow together seamlessly, creating a fast-paced dance of reflexes that feels as buttery as it looks.

Where you'll get true immersion and scale in Battlefield to the point that you won't even be able to explore a full map without playing two or three matches, Call of Duty is about precision and intensity, and the new multiplayer maps are absolutely worth the time you'll spend grinding in them. They're tighter, the teams are smaller, and the gunplay is a lot faster.

SBMM vs. persistent lobbies is the biggest differentiator

Has Activision removed SBMM out of fear of Battlefield 6?

This is a big one. Battlefield 6 does have SBMM (skill-based matchmaking), meaning your matches are constantly reshuffled to put you against players of roughly-equal skill. It's a fair system, yes, but it can make multiplayer feel oddly sterile.

Black Ops 7, however, is going old-school. Developer Treyarch have announced that the game, at launch, will have persistent lobbies and no SBMM, which is something that COD players have been requesting.

This means you'll stay in the same match lobby between games, creating natural rivalries and that old-school sense of community over hours of playtime that we've missed since the Xbox 360 days. It's the kind of change that hardcore fans have been begging for, and it could make BO7's multiplayer far more social than Battlefield's.

Do you like your war simulator light-hearted?

Battlefield 6 has assured players it won't be chasing trends

Both studios have made it clear that they are doubling down on what defines their respective series. Battlefield 6 refuses to chase trends. There aren't going to be celebrity skins, pop-culture crossovers, or memes here. What you'll get is just grounded, gritty warfare. In fact, the studio even poked fun at Call of Duty's celebrity crossovers with one of their pre-launch trailers, which was a confident statement: "We know what we are."

Meanwhile, Call of Duty is playing a balancing act. The bevy of celebrity skins and even cartoons in the Black Ops 6 multiplayer from last year left a bad taste in the mouths of a major part of the player base, and after listening to their complaints, they stated in a community post that Black Ops 7 won't be carrying Black Ops 6's skins into its multiplayer. Its battle royale mode, Warzone, which is a standalone gameplay experience now, will continue to be the playground for all the pop-culture madness, but Black Ops 7 will still leave room for some wacky crossovers that the higher-ups convince themselves fit into the theme.

If you want a no-nonsense, boots-on-the-ground combat game that refuses to bow to trends, Battlefield 6 should be your pick. If you want the best of both worlds, where you get fast and fluid gameplay along with modern flair and a wall jumping mechanic, BO7 might have you covered instead.

item.title: Building an NVR on my NAS was the best decision for my home security (and sanity)
item.itunes:title: Building an NVR on my NAS was the best decision for my home security (and sanity)
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
I initially got into the home lab rabbit hole because of my Network-Attached Storage rig, but I’ve since moved on to dedicated virtualization platforms for server experiments. However, my NAS is still an important part of the setup, as it takes care of all my backup, data archival, and file-sharing needs. I also self-host a handful of services inside the NAS, including apps that help manage my smart home devices.

For example, I’ve ditched the third-party companion apps of security cameras and switched to Frigate as my Network Video Recorder tool. Like other self-hosted services, there are plenty of ways to deploy Frigate, and I could easily go down the ol' Docker container route. However, I refuse to host it on anything besides my NAS rig.

Frigate makes NVR management easy

I don't have to invest in a dedicated NVR hub, either

Starting with Frigate itself, my surveillance setup is a mixed bag of IP cameras that I’ve bought during sales over the years. In addition to their clunky and restrictive companion apps, managing my security cameras from different interfaces would be a test of patience. Leaving aside the fact that they’re from different brands, I’d still have to invest in a dedicated NVR device to access centralized management, object detection, motion tracking, and other security features.

But since I already have a custom-built storage server, I can just deploy Frigate on it and save my wallet from the extra costs. Compared to the likes of ZoneMinder, Frigate is light enough to run on mere SBCs, so it works well on my NAS. Frigate also has a pretty sleek UI and includes powerful machine-learning NVR features that can use the GTX 1080 I’ve installed in the NAS.

No more share permissions to deal with

Few things are as aggravating as creating NFS permissions

If you’re wondering why I keep highlighting my NAS as the hosting machine for Frigate, it’s because NVR tools can generate a lot of video footage in a few weeks. Had I tried running it on, say, my Proxmox node (I’ve tried to do this with ZoneMinder in the past), I’d have to slot an extra hard drive just to hoard the footage from all the cameras. And no, I refuse to configure NFS shares to connect the Frigate instance with NFS-based shares may deliver solid performance, but their permissions are a complete nightmare to manage – and I say that as someone who has spent many weekends pulling my hair out trying to troubleshoot authentication errors. SMB shares are much better in that regard, but I often work with unprivileged containers. Sure, it’s possible to mount network volumes to these secure containers using a handful of workarounds.

But considering that the Frigate container will end up saving all the footage to my NAS if I went down the network share route, it’s a lot easier to just deploy the NVR on the storage server and call it a day. Rather than dealing with the scourge of NFS permissions, all I had to do was select a dataset within my preferred storage pool before pairing my Frigate instance with my security cameras.

My Frigate server runs 24/7

Especially since I keep risky experiments away from my NAS

Home labs are experimental by their very nature, and trial-and-error is a normal aspect of tinkering with server projects. Between regular backups and excessive documentation, I have enough ways to recover my home lab if things go wrong. But even if I can restore the main server node after a botched experiment, I’d still have to spend some time waiting for the virtual guests to come back to life. That’s a problem for a security-oriented service like Frigate, which not only helps me manage my self-hosted app stack, but also scans the camera feed for suspicious activity.

Since I’ve got backups scheduled round the clock for server nodes, daily drivers, and family devices, my NAS remains operational all day. I’ve also spared it from wacky experiments, as I don’t want my precious data to become irrecoverable. This makes my NAS the perfect host machine for Frigate, and I don’t have to worry about the surveillance system going offline due to my tinkering shenanigans.

Deploying Frigate is a cakewalk on TrueNAS

I love TrueNAS for multiple reasons, and its solid app store is one of them. Rather than deploying Frigate as a Docker container inside a VM, I’ve used the NVR tool’s app on TrueNAS to deploy it. Better yet, the Frigate image on TrueNAS can be configured using a variety of menu-based settings and toggles instead of long YAML scripts. Combine the lack of reliance on network shares with the simple setup procedure on TrueNAS’ app store, and you can get Frigate up and running even if you don’t have any prior experience with Docker containers.

item.title: Heroic Games Launcher isn't just for the Steam Deck, and it's great for your PC too
item.itunes:title: Heroic Games Launcher isn't just for the Steam Deck, and it's great for your PC too
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
If you own a Steam Deck but you don't want to be limited to playing games on Steam, there's a good chance you've heard about the Heroic Games Launcher. We've covered it ourselves a few years back as a great way to bring Epic Games titles such as Fortnite to the Steam Deck.

But as great as Heroic is on Valve's handheld, that's not the end of its perks. This game launcher is also a great addition to your PC, and it can help reduce clutter and organize your games that much better. Let's take a look at why.

It's on all platforms

Yes, even macOS

The Steam Deck runs SteamOS, which is a Linux-based operating system largely based on Arch, but the thing about Heroic is that it's hardly limited to any one platform. The launcher is available for Arch-based Linux distros, yes, but it's also available for the vast majority of Linux package managers so you can play your games on any machine of your choosing.

And it's not just for Linux, either. It's also available on macOS and Windows. On macOS, you can still benefit from Wine to allow you to run a lot of Windows games on a Mac. You don't get all the benefits of Proton, which is exclusive to Linux, but it's still a big deal for anyone wanting to try PC gaming despite being stuck with a Mac.

Ultimately, that's still the biggest benefit of Heroic. On Windows, all games run natively, but Heroic makes it easy to bring a lot of these games to Linux and macOS through Proton and Wine. Plus, if any of those games also have a native build for that operating system, Heroic can also download the appropriate build to ensure you have the best experience. In fact, you can even choose the version of Wine, Proton (on Linux), or even Apple's Game Porting Toolkit (on macOS) to use with each game to ensure the best compatibility possible

All your games in one place

It's just more organized

It used to be that Steam held a near monopoly on PC gaming, but over time, companies have stepped up to the plate with storefronts of their own, focusing on more specific benefits. Epic Games has built a reputation for itself by giving away free games on a regular basis, and a platform like GOG is popular for offering DRM-free games and also making a lot of classic games available and functional on modern hardware.

The problem with this is that it can become hard to manage your games when you're keeping a Steam library, a library for Epic Games titles, and another one for GOG, or even things like the EA App or Ubisoft Connect. All of those separate apps mean you have more hoops to jump through to get to your games, and that's something Heroic Games Launcher addresses, and does so on all platforms.

Out of the box, Heroic Games Launcher integrates with both the Epic Games Store and GOG, so you can buy games and browse your library from both platforms within the same app. It also lets you sign into Amazon Prime Gaming, but I don't find this all too useful considering most games there are redeemed on the Epic Games Store and GOG anyway. item.title: These 6 open-source tools will make your Raspberry Pi even more useful
item.itunes:title: These 6 open-source tools will make your Raspberry Pi even more useful
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
The Raspberry Pi is already one of the most versatile small computers around, but open-source software is what truly unlocks its potential. With the right tools, you can turn it into a dashboard, server, automation hub, or even a robust monitoring system. Whether you use your Pi for home projects, learning, or self-hosting, these tools can significantly enhance its capabilities.

Manage your Pi from anywhere with Cockpit

A web-based system dashboard that simplifies Linux management

Cockpit turns your Raspberry Pi into a fully manageable server with a clean web interface. Once installed, it provides control over users, storage, networking, and services without requiring you to constantly type commands. You can even monitor CPU and memory usage in real time. For users who are comfortable with Linux but prefer a visual way to manage systems, Cockpit bridges the gap nicely.

It’s beneficial when you’re running multiple SBCs or Linux devices around your home. Instead of SSHing into each one, you can open a browser tab and handle updates or check logs from a central dashboard. This makes it ideal for both beginners and advanced users who value efficiency and productivity. You can even manage other machines remotely, making Cockpit an excellent foundation for a home lab.

Because it’s modular, you can extend Cockpit with additional panels. There are plugins for managing virtual machines, containers, storage, and networking tools. The flexibility and simplicity make it one of the best open-source tools for anyone running Raspberry Pi OS or another Linux-based distribution on their Pi.

Block unwanted ads and trackers with Pi-hole

A self-hosted DNS sinkhole that improves network privacy

Pi-hole has become a household name for Raspberry Pi enthusiasts, and for good reason. It acts as a local DNS filter, blocking ad servers and tracking domains for every device on your network. Once you set it up, you’ll notice websites loading faster and your devices consuming less data. It’s a set-it-and-forget-it tool that improves both privacy and performance.

The web dashboard gives you detailed insight into how your network communicates. You can see which domains are being requested, which were blocked, and which devices are the busiest. This visibility can be addictive for anyone who enjoys understanding their network’s behavior. It’s also helpful for identifying rogue devices or apps that constantly phone home.

Pi-hole works excellently as a standalone tool, but it’s even better when paired with Unbound for encrypted, recursive DNS resolution. This combination creates a secure and private setup where your Raspberry Pi becomes your own DNS authority. Few open-source tools deliver such tangible benefits with so little ongoing maintenance.

Simplify container management with Portainer

A user-friendly interface for Docker and self-hosted apps

If you’re running Docker on your Raspberry Pi, Portainer is almost essential. It’s an open-source tool that provides a visual dashboard for managing containers, images, networks, and volumes. Instead of typing out complex docker commands, you can spin up or tear down applications with a few clicks.

This tool shines when you’re experimenting with self-hosted apps. From deploying Nextcloud to managing Uptime Kuma, Portainer keeps your projects organized. It makes troubleshooting containers that won’t start or pulling images directly from Docker Hub easier. The lightweight design means it runs flawlessly even on a Pi 4 or Zero 2 W.

Portainer is also a great learning aid. If you’re still getting comfortable with Docker concepts, the interface provides visual feedback on what’s happening under the hood. Once you understand it, you can transition back to the command line or continue using the web dashboard for convenience. Either way, it’s a must-have for any modern Raspberry Pi setup.

Automate your environment with Home Assistant

A powerful automation platform for your smart devices

Home Assistant transforms a Raspberry Pi into a capable home automation hub. It integrates with thousands of smart devices and services, enabling you to create customized automations that simplify your life. From turning lights on when you arrive home to monitoring temperature and air quality, it does everything.

What makes Home Assistant so appealing is its open-source foundation and active community. You’ll find countless add-ons and integrations created by users who love extending its capabilities. Whether you’re using Zigbee, Z-Wave, or Wi-Fi devices, you’ll likely find support for them within minutes. It’s the tool that ties your smart ecosystem together.

Once you become familiar with YAML configuration and the Home Assistant dashboard interface, the possibilities feel limitless. The Raspberry Pi handles it surprisingly well, especially when paired with an SSD for faster response times. This is one project where your Pi becomes more than a computer; it becomes the core of your smart home.

Build IoT workflows with Node-RED

A visual programming tool for connecting devices and data

Node-RED is one of the most creative ways to make your Raspberry Pi interact with the world around it. It’s an open-source, flow-based programming tool that lets you connect sensors, APIs, and online services using a simple drag-and-drop interface. If you’ve ever wanted your Pi to react to data or events, Node-RED is the easiest way to make it happen.

Each node in Node-RED performs a specific function, from reading GPIO inputs to sending notifications or HTTP requests. You can create logic chains that respond to time, temperature, or sensor data. The visual layout makes it easy to debug and extend as your projects grow more complex. It’s ideal for IoT experimentation or as a home automation add-on.

For makers who prefer not to write code from scratch, Node-RED opens up a new world of automation. You can even integrate it with Home Assistant or MQTT for seamless communication between systems. It’s one of those tools that’s simple enough to start with, but deep enough to grow alongside your skills.

Monitor performance and data with Grafana and InfluxDB

A data visualization powerhouse for your home lab

Grafana and InfluxDB together turn your Raspberry Pi into a rich monitoring platform. InfluxDB stores time-series data from sensors, services, or other devices, while Grafana turns that data into beautiful dashboards. Whether you’re tracking CPU load, temperature, or smart home metrics, the combination provides real insight into your system’s behavior.

Setting them up is easier than you might think. InfluxDB handles the storage backend, and Grafana connects to it for visualization. You can customize dashboards to display anything from ping times to power usage. It’s perfect for keeping tabs on your network or collecting environmental data from sensors around your home.

Because both are open-source, the possibilities are endless. You can integrate them with Node-RED, Home Assistant, or external APIs. Many Raspberry Pi owners use them to build full observability stacks for their home servers or IoT devices. Once you start visualizing your data, you’ll never want to go back to text logs again.

A single Pi, endless possibilities with open-source tools

Open-source software is what truly unlocks the Raspberry Pi’s potential.

Open-source software continues to redefine what the Raspberry Pi can do. From managing systems to visualizing data, these tools enhance your Pi’s capabilities and efficiency. Whether you use it as a home lab, automation hub, or small server, the right combination of software turns this tiny computer into something truly remarkable.

Home Assistant transforms a Raspberry Pi into a capable home automation hub. Open-source software continues to redefine what the Raspberry Pi can do. From managing systems to visualizing data, these tools enhance your Pi’s capabilities and efficiency. item.title: Why an immutable distro is the perfect starting point for new Linux users
item.itunes:title: Why an immutable distro is the perfect starting point for new Linux users
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
Linux has a bit of a reputation associated with it, and depending on your computer background, that reputation can be positive or negative in connotation. It's the OS built for servers, tinkerers, and developers, and not for the weak-minded. Its incredible robustness and flexibility often feel like a curse rather than a blessing for those who haven't been well exposed to it, and often times that can turn many users away from it for good.

Immutable distros have been helping flip that script. They're built to be reliable, hard to break, and far less intimidating than their mutable counterparts. Operating systems like Bazzite, Fedora Silverblue and openSUSE Aeon are changing what it means to run a Linux system, offering an experience that is often safer, more consistent, and way more friendly to new users. If you've ever wanted to try Linux, an immutable distro can be the perfect place to jump in with both feet.

What is an immutable Linux distribution?

Linux with guardrails

On a traditional, mutable Linux operating system, the base system files are writable. Everything goes; you and your apps can change anything at will, giving an incredible amount of flexibility, but it also can mean your system feels fragile. Updates can conflict, dependencies can clash, and things can be easily overwritten and lost forever.

An immutable operating system is essentially the opposite. The base system files are persistent, read-only, and are isolated meaning you're limited in the changes you can make. Much of the damage you could do on a normal distro is completely mitigated by this approach, but you can still install applications and use the system as you normally would.

A big safety net is important

Seemingly innocuous changes can result in a broken system

One of the biggest hurdles for new Linux users is the fear of breaking something, and on most distros, that fear is 100% justified. I can't tell you how many times I've edited the wrong configuration file, tried to uninstall a package I didn't fully understand, and ended up breaking something.

Immutable distros largely eliminate that problem. Because the core system is read-only, you can’t accidentally corrupt it. If something goes wrong with an update, you just reboot and roll back to the previous state, which is known as an "atomic" design. For a newcomer learning Linux, that kind of safety net is super important, and will definitely come in handy.

Applications don't get in your way

And updates are simple

For the experienced Linux user, keeping up with updates, installing applications, and fixing conflicts can seem like business as usual, but for someone coming from Windows or macOS, that burden can be a little too much to bear. They expect to install something and have it work regardless of what other changes they may make on their system, and thankfully, immutable distros handle that burden for you.

With a package manager like Flatpak, you can ensure any dependencies your favorite applications need are installed and kept separate from everything else on your system. All applications are self-contained, and you don't need to worry about one app update breaking another.

That consistency also makes online help far more reliable. If you’re running Bazzite 42, your base system is identical to everyone else’s using that version. Troubleshooting guides actually match your setup instead of sending you down a rabbit hole of missing packages or outdated repos.

Which immutable distros should you try?

The answer depends on what you plan to do on your system

Not all immutable distros are built the same, some are tuned for gamers, others for general desktop use. Bazzite is a Fedora-based immutable distro specifically built for gamers. It includes up-to-date drivers, Proton, Steam, and handheld compatibility out of the box. If you want something for gaming that just works, start there.

For general use, Fedora Silverblue or Kinoite are immutable flavors of Fedora with GNOME and KDE desktop environments, respectively. These are ideal for someone who just wants a clean, stable system. Additionally, openSUSE Aeon takes openSUSE's reliability and adds immutability, giving you another user-friendly KDE option.

Honestly, you can't really go wrong with any of these. No matter which one you start with, the common thread is the same: you can’t really mess it up, unless you really try to. Every option lets you explore Linux without worrying about breaking your install.

A better way to learn Linux

Whether you've been affected by the sunsetting of Windows 10 or if you’re just tired of Windows updates breaking your setup, even if you're apprehensive about trying Linux, try an immutable distro. It's a really great way to get your feet wet in a Linux environment without needing to worry about breaking it. Explore them (or even a mutable distro) in a VM, and see which ones you like.
